When a small group of living organisms (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return to the main population), it often finds itself in a different environment from that in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it had before.
The original population has not changed at all, it always needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble less and less the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will appear so different that they cannot be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

The technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense that the fate of humanity is dictated by a underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: technological development itself occurs beyond the cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new methods of production are being developed to reduce the cost of ownership of a car.
The massive possession of cars also leads to a greater incidence of road accidents, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat bodily injuries.

The "wagonways" were built in England as early as the 16th century.

This has become a common practice, but iron caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.

The first public reading of the document took place in the hall of the Independence Hall on July 8.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and private vehicles between two points, and the interactions they exert between them.

Unfortunately, drivers tend to act within a reasonably consistent range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonably consistent coherence and can be approximated mathematically.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) bandwidth, (2) density and (3) speed.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 9th century BCE, and was used by Phoenicians, Romans and Almohads as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who after it had been destroyed had rebuilt it and named it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after a earthquake.
The Sultan of Morocco rebuilt the city under the name of Daru l-Badya and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all Morocco for shopping.

The Sundarbans were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests, however, are not composed only of mangrove swamps. They also contain some of the last vestiges of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.

The two towers are 83 metres high; it is 378 metres long and has two lanes of 3.50 metres wide.

The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when Brazilian customs posts should be completed.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands Pound (FKP) which is equivalent to one pound sterling (GBP).

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang from each side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a safety problem: the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has one foot caught in the saddle, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First, most riders wear riding boots with a smooth and narrow heel and sole.

Violent weather is the generic term for any dangerous meteorological phenomenon that may cause damage, serious social disruption or loss of human life.
Weather conditions that are very unfavorable can occur anywhere in the world, and they can be of several kinds, depending on the geographical, topographic and atmospheric characteristics.
Strong winds, hail, excessive rainfall, and wildfires are all forms and effects of violent weather, just as thunderstorms, tornadoes, tidal waves, and cyclones are.
Extreme weather phenomena, regional and seasonal, include cold storms, snow storms with strong winds, and sandstorms or dust storms.
It is strongly advised that travellers should enquire about the weather risks that may affect their destination region, knowing that this may have an impact on the itineraries they intend to take.
